all fixed now\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2023-03-15T19:10:14.748Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":49,"readers_count":48,"score":29.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":430367,"topic_slug":"spark-max-flashing-in-and-out-of-connection","display_username":"Vincent","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51176,"hidden":false,"trust_level":0,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/spark-max-flashing-in-and-out-of-connection/430367/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3166725,"name":"","username":"Hybrid_Piper","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/h/f05b48/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-03-17T12:43:19.690Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eProfessionally, any time I see a CAN problem on a vehicle I immediately go and check the resistance.  I did this with our FRC robot as well.  At each end of the CAN line is a 120 ohm terminating resistor.  With FRC, one terminating resistor is in the RoboRio and the other is in the power distribution panel.  \u003cstrong\u003eWith the power off\u003c/strong\u003e, disconnect one end and using a multimeter you should be able to see 120 ohms.  If you connect the whole CAN line, you should see 60 ohms as both are in parallel.  If you see anything other than 60 or 120 ohms, you have a wiring problem.  This can help locate the wiring issue.\u003c/p\u003e","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2023-03-17T12:43:19.690Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":35,"readers_count":34,"score":12.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":430367,"topic_slug":"spark-max-flashing-in-and-out-of-connection","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":58014,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/spark-max-flashing-in-and-out-of-connection/430367/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3166779,"name":"Max Morehead","username":"Max_Morehead","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/max_morehead/{size}/231937_2.png","created_at":"2023-03-17T14:22:36.998Z","cooked":"\u003cp\u003eWe had a problem with a spark max flashing erratically, and the problem was that the neo’s encoder cable was bad.
